topic.title: How to setup a TOR v3 tracker on Ubuntu 20.04 and Linux Mint 20.2 using Anonymoose's patch.
topic.body:
First, go [here](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1627703143_17NZ2BiZ1HUYppUcUmU5bgyGkp8kH7UyXj/Zeronet+v3+tor+hidden+service+support+Is+out) and install the patch.

Open Terminal.

```sudo passwd```

Set the superuser password.

Follow the instructions linked below. Your distribution is focal. use ```sudo su``` if permission is denied.

https://community.torproject.org/onion-services/setup/install/

```sudo nano /etc/tor/torrc```

[Follow these directions.](/1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/faq/)

Include these lines:

```
HiddenServiceDir /var/lib/tor/ZeroNet
HiddenServicePort 15441 127.0.0.1:15441
```

Ctrl+O to write to the file.

Enter to save.

Ctrl+X to exit.

```systemctl restart tor```

Now, navigate to /var/lib/tor/ZeroNet.

Open hostname.

Copy the hostname and paste it to the "File server external IP" textarea on [this page](/Config). Also paste it to the Trackers textarea with zero:// before the hostname. Include :15441 for Trackers.

Example:

#File server external IP
```
my562dxpjropcd5hy3nd5pemsc4aavbiptci5amwxzbelmzgkkuxpvid.onion
```

#Trackers
```
zero://my562dxpjropcd5hy3nd5pemsc4aavbiptci5amwxzbelmzgkkuxpvid.onion:15441
```
Have Tor set to Enabled or Always. Use File server port 15441.

Enable Bootstrapper plugin [here](/Plugins).

Important: Only ever shutdown ZeroNet from ZeroHello or when prompted from the Config or Plugins pages. Never update+restart ZeroNet with the Py3 Updater.

Please always keep your PC running.

Share your tracker(s) here. They will be included in [Syncronite](/15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o) if they're working.

topic.title: Both České fórum and the ZeroNet Mobile forum need to revert back to ZeroTalk's JS.
VFX Artists DEBUNK Pentagon UFO Videos
topic.body:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jHDlfIaBEqw

_I actually did the math myself on the "parallax" or "go fast" video. There are a lot of numbers visible in the HUD in that video, and all you need is some trigonometry to figure it out. It's an object about 1,5 to 2 meters large. Which is normal albatross/pelican size. It is halfway between the ground and the airplane, which is normal albatross/pelican flying height. The speed of the fast military airplane is making the background whoosh past through parallax effect, even though the object itself is travelling at a measly 60 kmph. Which is normal albatross/pelican flying speed. It is also normal wind speed at that altitude, so it might even be travelling with the wind like a balloon does. Literally the only weird thing about it is that it looks quite cold. Way colder than I expect a bird to be. Since balloons are cold, maybe that's a better match. Though I don't know if a bird might just look really cold thanks to its insulative feathers, even though it is not cold. EDIT: As you can see in a later comment in this thread, people became annoyed at this so I actually checked this part as best I could now, aaaand it turns out even the temperature is correct for a bird._

_I also analyzed the the "gimbal" video to similar degree. And that video is similarily mundane. The apparent rotation of the object is not the object itself rotating; it is clearly the camera gimbal rotating, because it is changing the shape of the aberrations around literally everything in the image, including the clouds in the background and small smudges on the lens. All of these things are rotated the exact same way at the exact same time. So it is clearly not the object rotating, it is the camera gimbal rotating, and the video we are seeing is an auto-rotated image-stabilized view, as the automatic tracking reaches the end of one axis and must rotate to continue the tracking motion. The odd flying saucer shape of the object is a LENS FLARE due to the camera getting blinded by the object, probably because it is reflective to infrared light, and the airplane itself is irradiating the object with an infrared tracking laser, which is bouncing back towards the airplane. OR it is simply reflecting the sun. It is reflecting something bright anyway. Since the shape is a lens flare it will rotate with the cameras aperture, and not with the object itself, which is most likely not rotating at all. This was filmed off the coast of Orlando, Florida, and that area is prone to aluminium mylar helium balloons escaping from Disney World. Those are reflective in this manner._

topic.title: $1,000 USD down the drain.
topic.body:
So, earlier this year I bought a Samsung Galaxy S10+ 1TB. It was only available through Amazon, not the Samsung website. I thought this was fine, but four months later, the phone started randomly turning off without warning and eventually stopped turning on as the battery had a negative charge, indicated by uBreakiFix. I can buy a new battery for it from J&J International, but I can't find anyone to install the battery.

My mother and I went through all the hoops necessary: Samsung, Asurion, Amazon, uBreakiFix, and the seller Endlessitems17, back and forth. Endlessitems17 is a third party seller, so keep that in mind. The phone, it turns out, was purchased by me ten months after the factory warranty expired, thus putting me in a pickle. Nothing we tried was fruitful. My mother answered questions by potential buyers that the phone arrived out of factory warranty. Endlessitems17 said they'd replace the phone, first sending the shipping label to us, which never happened -- weeks have passed by without the label arriving. Endlessitems17 had said that we need to send EVERYTHING THAT WAS IN THE BOX back with the phone once the shipping label arrived, and, well, you already know that didn't happen.

So, long story short, don't buy an expensive gadget from a third party, nor from Amazon for that matter, as the phone was ordered through Amazon and I've received defective and used PC parts from Amazon in the past while they were supposed to be brand new and I had to pay return shipping!

Amazon is not the place to buy expensive goods. Just forget about it. Save yourself the money, time and headaches and forget about getting one of the last 1TB phones left on Earth available for purchase. It's just not worth it. That's 1.5 months of my hard work down the drain.

I'm warning you, because nobody deserves what happened to me.

The lesson here is to buy directly from the manufacturer as you'll get a factory warranty and the option to pay for insurance.

topic.title: user-scalable=1 really sucks when you have a shaking disorder
topic.body:
Suppose you have shaking induced by medication or Parkinson's. You'd be accidentally tapping the screen repeatedly, zooming in and out a lot.

I recommend you set your viewport in content.json like so:

```
 "viewport": "width=device-width, initial-scale=0.8, user-scalable=0",
```

And if your page is supposed to be viewed in raw/, then set the viewport in the html file(s) as well:

```
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=.8, user-scalable=0" />
```

These viewport settings also make your page(s) look good on mobile devices.

Please, everyone, set your viewport(s).

I don't have an issue with shaking anymore, because of an additional medication, but it was extremely annoying while it lasted.

topic.title: Complete Malware Blockage
topic.body:
I have malware blocking on my new ASUS router (Any OS). I also block malware with [AdGuard AdBlocker](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/android/addon/adguard-adblocker/) (Any OS). Oh, and let's not forget [Safing Portmaster](https://safing.io/portmaster/) (Ubuntu and Windows). Lastly, I use [Quad9's anti-malware DNS](https://support.quad9.net/hc/en-us/articles/360041193212-Quad9-IPs-and-other-settings) (Any OS), so I'm blocking malware at every level: browser, OS, router, and DNS.

If you're an Apple fanatic, then try [Lockdown Privacy](https://lockdownprivacy.com/).

You can test your choice malware blocker(s) [here](https://www.wicar.org/test-malware.html).

What do you use on desktop computers? Please mention OS support. The wider OS support, the better.

> [saqat](#comment_10_14NiXkEXrFAHokAohyiCv5PCAXLcEsvEUp): What does Syncronite do?

Syncronite syncs with anonymoose's and ngosang's trackers lists, merges them together as Syncronite.html and publishes using crontab which periodically executes Syncronite.sh from my laptop.

Nothing is executed from your device, so there are no external calls. All you get is an hourly-updated trackers list.

You can see the trackers list [here](/raw/15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o/cache/1/Syncronite.html).

1630827774_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
In index.html, link to the CSS and JS files with **?v={site_modified}** following the file name.

Examples:

```
<link rel="stylesheet" href="css/all.css?v={site_modified}" />
```
```
<script type="text/javascript" src="js/all.js?v={site_modified}"></script>
```

This will flush the browser cache for the site in question whenever the peer refreshes the page after you publish changes. Everyone should be using this feature. I didn't propose it for nothing.

[This is Syncronite.sh](/list/15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o/cache/1/?file=cache/1/Syncronite.sh)

A BitTorrent tracker is a special type of server that assists in the communication between peers using the BitTorrent protocol.

In peer-to-peer file sharing, a software client on an end-user PC requests a file, and portions of the requested file residing on peer machines are sent to the client, and then reassembled into a full copy of the requested file. The "tracker" server keeps track of where file copies reside on peer machines, which ones are available at time of the client request, and helps coordinate efficient transmission and reassembly of the copied file. Clients that have already begun downloading a file communicate with the tracker periodically to negotiate faster file transfer with new peers, and provide network performance statistics; however, after the initial peer-to-peer file download is started, peer-to-peer communication can continue without the connection to a tracker.

1594083595_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body: ```while true; do inotifywait -e modify,create,delete,move -r /path/to/your/dir && \ python3 zeronet.py siteSign address --publish done```

```
#! /bin/sh
USERNAME="styromaniac"
ZERONET_ROOT_DIR="/home/${USERNAME}/ZeroNet"
SITE_ADDRESS="15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o"
SH_DIR="${ZERONET_ROOT_DIR}/data/${SITE_ADDRESS}/cache/1/"
V3_TRACKERS="127.0.0.1:43110/raw/13hNAdge5ntxJmcnKzAxeLCuyowJkdvFxF/trackers/v3_trackers.html"
CLEARNET_TRACKERS="https://ngosang.github.io/trackerslist/trackers_all_ip.txt"
OUTFILE1="${SH_DIR}v3_trackers.html"
TEMPFILE1="${OUTFILE1}.new"
OUTFILE2="${SH_DIR}_h_.html"
TEMPFILE2="${OUTFILE2}.new"

RESPONSE_CODE=$(curl --write-out "%{response_code}" "${V3_TRACKERS}" --output "${TEMPFILE1}")

# If something went wrong getting v3_trackers.html
if [[ ${RESPONSE_CODE} != 200 ]]; then
  # Erase the temporal file and exit
  rm -f "${TEMPFILE1}"
  exit 1
fi

# Replace the old v3 trackers file with the new one
mv "${TEMPFILE1}" "${OUTFILE1}"

RESPONSE_CODE=$(curl --write-out "%{response_code}" "${CLEARNET_TRACKERS}" --output "${TEMPFILE2}")

# If something went wrong getting trackers_all_ip.txt
if [[ ${RESPONSE_CODE} != 200 ]]; then
  # Erase the temporal file and exit
  rm -f "${TEMPFILE2}"
  exit 1
fi

# Replace the old clearnet trackers file with the new one
mv "${TEMPFILE2}" "${OUTFILE2}"

#Combine trackers files into Syncronite.html
cat "${SH_DIR}v3_trackers.html" "${SH_DIR}_h_.html" > "${SH_DIR}Syncronite.html"

# Sign and publish
${ZERONET_ROOT_DIR}/zeronet.py siteSign "${SITE_ADDRESS}" --publish```
